segments.text: The lines are not essential.
I ask you how an interest came in chemical engineering that led to oceanography.
Okay.
I was interested in chemical engineering even before I started the college after World War II.

So I went immediately from the Navy to two years of science courses at Compton Junior College, then spent a semester at Fullerton Junior College, and then went to New Mexico A&M, where I decided to major in chemical engineering.
I graduated from A&M in 1950, and this was
at kind of a little depression in which there weren't a lot of company representatives out scouting for chemical engineers to go to work for their companies.
The reason I had gone to New Mexico to begin with was because a high school friend of mine, Art Maxwell, had gone there and recommended it.
Then
When he left New Mexico, and he graduated a year earlier than I did in physics, he went to Scripps to do some graduate work.
And he had told me how good it was.
And so I decided to try to apply my chemical engineering background, combined with the oceans,
to extracting chemicals from the sea and, in general, working with chemistry of the oceans.
So I went there in 1950, spent a year taking the required courses and working half time.
Then because Norris Rakestraw, who was chairman of the chemistry department at that time, required all of his chemical
people to go to UCLA for a year.
I went up to UCLA and did a year of graduate chemistry up there, then came back to Scripps, took some more courses, and got involved in working almost full-time.
So I got diverted from
getting my Ph.D.
I saw that you had not finished your thesis but had done all the work leading to your thesis.
Now were you diverted then working at Scripps because you were very active then in testing and chemical engineering at that particular time.
Were you working out of Scripps?
No, I was working at Scripps at the time.
I was doing some research with Ted Folsom which involved trying to do
extraction of chemical compounds at low temperatures out of the seawater, particularly looking at the organic problem.
And so I built a vacuum evaporator and used it in a series of small experiments.
We're in good shape.
Now, what I don't understand is, did your time in the Navy have any effect upon your decision to enter oceanography or chemical engineering?
I don't think so.
Okay.
What did you do while you were in the Navy?
I was a machinist mate, enlisted man, spent the entire, after the first year of training, the entire time on an LSD in the South Pacific.
It seemed to me like that would dampen the enthusiasm for oceanography.
When did they send you to UCLA?
Was that the general policy at Scripps at that time, to do a year study away from the institution in the hard sciences, so to speak?
It was Raichstraw's policy, because Scripps was, there was no UCSD at that time.
Scripps was a little campus down there all by itself, and he felt that chemical oceanographers should have a stronger grounding
in chemistry that he could give them at Scripps.
So he required them all to go spend a year at UCLA in the chemistry department.
Who else was at Scripps while you were there who might have had some influence on you?
Warren Wooster was there.
I worked for Warren from the day I went there.
John Isaac.
I worked for Ted Folsom and John Isaac for some time.
Ed Goldberg.
Does there seem to be any lead from Scripps to O.N.R.?
Yeah, Howard Maxwell.
Okay.
Now, what had happened was that both Art and I got involved in looking at the fallout of fission products from nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
And he had...
participated in, I think, the 54 series of tests.
And he got disinterested in it.
And Gordon Little came to Scripps and talked him into going to Washington about 1955 or something like that.
Maybe it was 56, 55.
Meanwhile, I was not working for Art at Scripps.
I was working for
with Folsom and Isaacs.

And in the 56 series of tests, after Art had gone, then I sort of took over the responsibility for that part of the testing that both he and Ted Folsom had been doing earlier in organizing and this sort of thing.
So I stayed until 1958.
And Vedder left.
O&R at that time, and Maxwell asked me if I'd like to come and go to work for O&R.
And I could see I wasn't going to get to work on my PhD, not because they wouldn't let me, but because of my own interests.
So I decided to go join Art in Washington and work for O&R.
Now, before we move into
such things as Washington experiences.
I only have a couple of more questions I would like to ask.
What exactly sorts of tests were you running on radioactive fallout?
Well, the key question that was being asked was how much of the fission products from a given bomb test go into the stratosphere and how much of it come down locally.
They couldn't measure what went into the stratosphere, but there was some hope that they could measure how much of it came down as local fallout.

And so we spent a lot of time building instruments to tow behind the ship, trying to map the aerial extent of the fallout and the depths to which it had penetrated, and trying to do a mass balance back to the bomb test.
And so it was instrument development,
data reduction, writing reports for Sandy on the results, and most of it was classified, secret.
Now then, after this series of experiments then,
Off you go to Washington.
And exactly what prompted the change from academic to managerial life then seems to be a feeling you prefer not to finish a PhD thesis.
Then when you come to work for ONR, what exactly do you do?
Well, I went to work in the geophysics branch.
And at that time, it was being run by Gordon Lill, who
He was a geologist himself.
And Maxwell, who was responsible for oceanography.
And it had an atmospheric arm, Jim Hughes, and a solid earth geology program under, I can't think of his name now.
But anyway, I essentially went there to help Art manage the program, their research program at the academic institution.

And the first thing I did with Art and Gordon was to write a 10-year plan for the Navy's program in oceanographic research called TENOC, and that document was used by the Navy as a planning document for expanding oceanography in the U.S. What sort of research did you seek to aid while you were at O.N.
Art?
Were you mission-oriented or war-oriented or hard science-oriented?

Well, in 1958, when I went there, and for the early part of the 60s, it was our conviction and the conviction of the people at ONR, Chief of Naval Research and others, that just about any research that you do on the oceans is going to help the Navy since that's the Navy's operating environment.
So we were essentially...
While we had a mission orientation, the composition of the research program that we supported wasn't restricted in any way.
It was all unclassified, all basic, and not restricted to one discipline or another.
It wasn't until Mansfield Amendment of 1966 or something like that that the Navy became concerned about
the orientation of its, particularly ONR, the orientation of its basic research program.
But even then, we didn't, I don't think we had to lop off 5% of what we were supporting.
It was still justifiable, highly justifiable under the Navy's banner.
Did you try to create academic departments in academe as departments of oceanography in this period?
Yes, we did.
There were five institutions in 1958.
Scripps, Woods Hole, University of Washington, Texas A&M, and Miami.
And I guess Lamont was there, but we weren't supporting it.

And what we said in Tannock was that there was not enough oceanographic capability in the country to satisfy the Navy's needs for basic research in this area, and that we should build laboratories using ONR funds.
Not, yes, build them, but help the people build them.
So Wayne Burt went to Oregon State University, and we supported him.
in building up his capability, supplied him with a ship from the Navy's funds, supported his research program as it expanded.
John Knauss went to the University of Rhode Island.
O&R supported the buildup of his program, made available the funds to convert one of the FS class research vessels.
We had also, in that 10-year plan, planned to expand the existing institutions at a rate of about 10% a year for 10 years.
And we had a shipbuilding program to go with it.
And we made ships available to Lamont, Scripps, Miami, Woods Hole.
And we built some buildings.
We built the building at the Johns Hopkins University
the Chesapeake Bay Institute, primarily with ONR funds, under amortization.
They build it, and then we let them amortize the cost over 10 years at 8% a year, over 8 years at 10% a year.
So in general, that period of time was spent in ONR's building the oceanographic capability.
What about specific departments?
Suppose that you saw you needed a department of chemical engineering and oceanography someplace.
Would you tend to invite proposals of this sort to come in to encourage departmental growth?
No, I wouldn't say we didn't do that.
We may have in conversations with the laboratory directors encouraged the buildup of this or that or something else.
But we didn't really... We tried not to...
impinge too much on the university's prerogatives, which include building the kind of departments they want.
Yeah, right.
Did you have any ratio about which you tried to divide funds up?
Did you try to work the funds out equally in terms of sections or in terms of universities, or primarily you organized them around the caliber of the proposals, or both?
Well, as in most of these programs,
It's partly trying to change the existing pattern of support and partly continuing to support what you supported last year.

And so I think the way we spent our money early in the game, we spent our money by essentially discussing what the major institutions would be doing during the coming year and then supplying them with the funds without too much
deep review on the individual projects.
It was really block support to institutions.

And then, that was about the time of the Mansfield Amendment and about the time that ONR restructured their program, got rid of the geophysics branch, organized an ocean sciences division, that we started doing harder and harder reviews and building a team of experts.
Up until
Up until the time that they established the Ocean Sciences Division, there were only two oceanographers in the geophysics branch.
Artis had me as chief oceanographer, and then we hired Don Martineau and
I mean, I can't tell you.
My memory doesn't carry that well right now.
All right, now, two comments have appeared in the course of other interviews.
Some oceanographers have maintained that it was better in terms of research facilities when ONR simply gave block funds and allowed the university itself to distribute it, like Scripps.
Others have argued that they now prefer it the way it is now, that it's closely looked over projects,
with sort of careful review of proposals.
Now, the people who advocate the block funds maintain that it was more experimental then.
This was a better chance for a person without a national reputation to come into research funds.
The others maintain that now you receive more money for your research.
Do you have any opinion one way or another on that?
Well, I suppose that
Certainly the awarding of block funds to the institute directors gave them more flexibility in supporting the kind of research that they wanted to support.
And in a sense, I suppose, that provided more flexibility because there were more people making the decisions and a broader base.
I don't think the way we're doing it now
is hampered.
I don't think that the flexibility of the way we're doing it now is hampered as much by the administrative procedures as it is by funding.
I think if the directors, who at that time were getting fair increases every year and building, they had a lot of spare cash to work with.
I think if they were faced with what they've been faced with for the past four or five or 10 years maybe,
they would have not been so flexible either.
And so I don't think it's the system that cuts down the flexibility as much as it is the growth or collapse of the field.
Now, growth of the field.
Others have suggested that the plethora of institutions created in the late 50s, early 60s divided the research pie up to the extent that worthy projects are now very difficult to get funded.
Would you agree?
I don't know.
I think from IDOE's point of view, I don't believe that's the case.
It may be because of ONR's difficulties over the past five years, level funding, in the face of galloping inflation, that that's a real impact.
But the establishment of IDOE at least made funds available for big, exciting programs to be carried out.
Now, a few comments about these, if you shall.
Roger Revelle, when did you first meet him and what sort of impact did he have on ONR by the time you arrived?
Well, I met Roger at Scripps when I went there, but his impact on ONR was before 1950.
In fact, I think he was either the first
geophysics branch head as a commander in the Navy.
I think that's what he was.
And he essentially shaped the geophysics branch at that time.
So I don't know what other impact he had at ONR, but he certainly established oceanography within the geophysics branch and left people behind who were sympathetic to oceanography.
Yeah, Tom.
Were there any oceanographers in particular who seemed to have a national impact on ONR at this time?
That is, whose opinions were so valued that they perhaps swayed ONR in both giving funds or what have you?
Oh, I think, as I said earlier, we were dealing directly with the laboratory directors and supporting them in sort of a block basis.
And certainly the laboratory directors probably had the major impact on ONR's oceanography program.
And I would defend that even today because our attitude then was that
What's good for the science, oceanographic science, is good for the Navy, because the Navy doesn't have the wisdom to know what ought to be done in basic oceanographic research.
And much of it didn't exist in Washington.
So we worked very closely with them, and they certainly had an impact on the shape of the program and on the kind of work that was being supported.
And that included Roger and
Columbus Islin, Fritz Kochi, John Canone.
Why NSF?
Why did you decide to separate NSF and ONR, and why did you decide to go with NSF?
I didn't understand the first part of that.
There's evidently a decision made, and ONR participates in it, best I can tell, for NSF to grow and to separate from ONR.
What was the basic philosophy behind the National Science Foundation, and why did you decide to go with NSF?
Well, I don't think that ONR was involved in the decision to establish
the National Science Foundation.
I think some of the high people in ONR probably encouraged it to expand the base of basic research.
But the foundation was really established by an act of Congress.
And that was done long before I ever thought of joining the foundation.
That was done, I can't tell you the exact date, but in the early 50s.
And some of the people high up in ONR did come to the foundation.
Randy Robertson is the one that comes to mind first.
But a lot of other people from ONR who had experience in this kind of basic research administration.
My decision to come to the foundation was really because a number of people
put the arm on me.

And these included Worth Mallon from Texas A&M, who had been working with Jerry Van Andel and John Ryder to hold the decade program together in its first few months until the director could be found for the IDOE program.
And Tom Owen, who at that time had just assumed responsibility for
the research directorate, national and international programs, and was responsible for the IDOE program.
And I couldn't think of a good reason not to accept it.
It was a promotion, and it was a challenge.
And while I was enjoying myself tremendously at ONR, and I hated to leave, I just felt that I couldn't afford, I just couldn't turn it down.
What sort of new direction did you try to bring to the foundation now that you have a new job removed from O&R?
How did you visualize its role in the future?

I didn't, you know, I was in O&R during the planning stages of IDOE and we had some minor input into it, although the Navy had somebody who was responsible sort of on a full-time basis for the planning.
But I looked on it as a pork barrel, which we could tap out of the O and R to augment our ongoing program.
And we put together some pretty big projects that we felt justify funds from this new source of money.
But when I came over here, then my attitude changed a little bit.
And I had no real preconceived notions about what the IDOE program should look like.
And until I agreed to join it, I had not read very much about the background, the documents, or anything else.

And I spent several months working with the troika that was trying to hold it together, and reading all the background documents, and trying to decide what the philosophy should be, what kind of projects we should support.
and how we should implement the program.
So I didn't have any bright ideas when I came over here.
And I think the decision was pretty well made that we should reserve this new source of funds for tackling some difficult problems that we had not been able to tackle before.
And then the problem was, which, you know,
which research project should be undertaken, and how should we deal with the whole matter of initiating a project, reviewing it, managing it, the whole business.
And it evolved.
We made a lot of mistakes in the first year, so it evolved gradually over a long period of time.
In the first several years, what sort of basic decision did you make, let's say, difference in reviewing and managing than you had at ONR in projects?
A couple of major differences.
At ONR, the procedure at that time, and still is for that matter, is to do a review of a proposal from an institution.
with all of its components, maybe 20, 30 tasks under one proposal, with the staff.

That is, the staff, which was at that time about six oceanographers, to go and spend three or four days in an institution, talking to the people who had made the proposals, and then sitting down and making the decisions right there on which ones they would support, at what level, and which ones they would not support.
When I came over here, the foundation's method was to use peer review, male review, and external review panels.
And in a way, it gives you a broader base of advice, and you're less susceptible to criticism.
I take it you prefer then the foundation method of reviewing proposals.
You want to shut that off for a minute?
You're supposed to be talking too much.
Where did we leave off?
I asked you, I said, I take it you prefer the way that the foundation now reviews proposals.
Yeah, I think it's...

for what we're doing i think it's better i think onr who has the mission orientation problem can still go ahead and run the program that way without you know they have good people and they support good scientists i don't think they have any problem for us for us it's better and uh
sort of assures that the research you're doing is really excellent and not just the bias of one program manager or one person.
Now, while at ONR you co-authored a pamphlet on the next 10 years of oceanography, would you hazard to say where you think oceanography is going to go within the next several years?
What direction will it take?
I've already done that twice.
I guess you could surely identify the major issues that face the nation and the country over the next 10 or 20 years with regard to the oceans.
And one of them is certainly climate.
Physical oceanography is certainly going to pay close attention to the impact of the ocean on extended weather forecasting, on weather, and on climate.
We're going to be concerned with the quality of the ocean as far as man's impact on that with his own waste products.
And a lot of work is going to be done in marine pollution and marine pollution studies over the next five or 10 years.
We will be deeply involved in our research.
And the federal program will be equally deeply involved in the non-living resources.
The petroleum, it's the kind of thing we're supporting, and we're only at the beginning of it.
Manganese nodules, how they form.

And in living resources, the whole problem of intelligent management of fisheries resources, based on the system or the ecology of the region, rather than just a given fish or a given species, this sort of thing.
